title: "Married" Soup
introduction: The Minestra Maritata, or 'Married' Soup, is a heartwarming Italian dish from Naples where the flavors of assorted meats and vegetables culminate in a flavorful union. This ancient recipe was traditionally a staple, allowing people to make use of various leftover meats and vegetables to create a delicious and fulfilling meal. While it may be considered somewhat vintage today, its ability to provide comfort and warmth on a cold day makes it a cherished dish for many.
ingredients: 1 pound meaty pork ribs (country-style pork ribs)
1 thick slice imported Italian prosciutto (about 4 ounces)
1 pound (1 medium bunch) broccoli rabe, trimmed
1 pound (about half of a small head) savoy cabbage, cut into strips
8 ounces broccoli, cut into florets (about 2 cups)
instructions: In a large pot, bring 5 quarts water to a boil. Add the pork ribs, prosciutto bone (if using), carrots, celery, and onion. Lower the heat to a simmer and cook 30 minutes over medium heat.
Skim off the foam that rises to the surface. Add the sausage, prosciutto, soppressata, and crushed red pepper. Cook until the pork ribs are tender, about 2 hours.

Meanwhile, wash and trim all of the vegetables. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add half the greens. Bring to a simmer and cook 10 minutes. With a slotted spoon, transfer the greens to a colander set over a large bowl. Cook the remaining greens the same way. Drain well and let cool. When cool, chop the greens into bite-size pieces.
After 2 hours cooking time, remove the meats and sausage from the broth. Discard the bones and cut the meats and sausage into bite-size pieces.

Let the broth cool slightly. Skim the fat from the broth. Strain the broth through a fine-mesh strainer into a large clean pot. Return the meats to the broth. Add the greens. Return to a simmer and cook 30 minutes.
Serve hot, sprinkled with grated Parmigiano-Reggiano.
variations: Chard, chicory, kale, or cabbage can be used instead of the vegetables listed.
Try Genoa or other Italian-style salami in place of the soppressata, or a ham bone instead of the prosciutto bone.
